summary: This document is a chain of emails from October 2020 and earlier (dating back to 2019) between the FBI's Litigation Support Unit/Information Management Division and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York regarding the Epstein investigation. The emails discuss the processing, scanning, and transfer of discovery materials, including CDs from Florida, and coordination on obtaining a complete set of records.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: The recipient of emails from the FBI's Litigation Support Unit regarding the Epstein investigation discovery materials; appears to be coordinating the receipt and review of scanned records.

events.title: FBI follow-up on Epstein investigation materials
events.description: Email from FBI Litigation Support Unit to AUSA following up on request for information about processing of Epstein investigation materials, specifically CDs from Florida.
personsInvolved: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York

events.title: Coordination on scanning Epstein records
events.description: Email discussing follow-up on conversations about transmitting scanned records from the Epstein investigation, referencing 16,000 vs. 29,000 pages and requesting an index of materials including media.
personsInvolved: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York

events.title: Initial contact regarding Epstein records
events.description: Email following up on a conversation about Epstein investigation records, providing contact information and offering to set up another call to discuss questions about the records.
personsInvolved: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York

keyFacts: The FBI's Litigation Support Unit was processing discovery materials related to the Epstein investigation, including CDs from Florida.

There was coordination between the FBI and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York regarding the scanning and transfer of thousands of pages of records (16,000 to 29,000 pages).
The emails reference the need to confirm that all materials received were scanned and to obtain an index or catalog of those materials, including media.
The correspondence shows ongoing communication about Epstein investigation records from at least January 2019 through October 2020.
